review_title: Enjoyable day to day but concerning decisions if interested in research, odd work load analysis approach.
pros: The day to day aspects of the job are great. Being an educator is a wonderful and rewarding job to have. Pay is lower than typical for the sector but this is also understandable given it's position. Excellent holidays.
cons:
The workload model is very focused on teaching and does not give any countenance for other sources of time that need to committed. This can make it seem you have little to do to senior management when you are working flat out. 

The Uni has taken some odd decisions with it's most successful and senior researchers, making many of them redundant. This sends the message that if successful you are at risk of redundancy and removes mentors / thought leaders from influence at the University.

review_title: Great opportunity to work while studying
pros: The university offers a variety of jobs for students that usually involve talking to prospective students and their parents about their student experience and helping at university events. This allows students to earn part-time cash, learn more about what the university is up to and meet different people who on the different teams working for the university. The events that I was able to be part of in my four years of university were one of the best expriences I had as a student and gave me so much knoweldge about academic life and opporutnities after graduation in academia.
cons: The pay is part-time and sometimes you might not get shifts for a long time so it is not a job for long-term earnings.

pros: colleagues were brilliant talented people
cons: leadership is detatched and autocratic

pros: Great Uni in a great town, range of sports teams
cons: lower salary than nearby London

pros: Good facilities and by the riverside and good food.
cons:
I was a student advocate in my first year. The lecturer shouted at me that because of what I had done that his course would not be on the Universities new biomedical science course. This lecturer then proceeded to make my life hell. I had black students come to me with similar experiences from this lecturer.

Not only that, the pharmacology lecturer asked are you are looney and called me a pootard. Despite all this I finished. 

I believe that If you value your sanity and don't want to be bullied (particularly as a BAME student). GO ELSEWHERE.

review_title: Don't risk it, your health will never recover
pros: I have to write something in this box apparently. There are some good people working there, not people who will ever advance at this vile institution, but there are a few here and there nonetheless.
cons: Whatever hours they say you will work, expect to work at least double (all overtime is unpaid, of course). A deeply ingrained culture of bullying and harassment. Research is no longer available to upwards of 80% of staff. Communication is lacking, management regularly reveal that they do not respect teaching staff in the slightest. They 'think teachers have it too easy'. Perhaps you could work here if you are white, middle class, male, straight, from Northampton locally, no desire to grow or advance your skills in any way, and with a tendency for sociopathy. Anybody else risks hostile mistreatment which is completely swept under the rug. Anything management tell you before you accept a job there can be entirely discarded - it will all change once you arrive. The institution, at every level - students, staff, and so forth - is focused on marketing and recruitment above all else. Like students, once you arrive it is a different story. Not to mention if you want a job that's still there in a few years, this is not the place to get it. They were predicted the most likely university to close following the pandemic, but it isn't because of the pandemic, it's because of the new Waterside building project which went enormously over budget and is still not fit for purpose. I have seen too many good people used, chewed up and spat out by this institution. People taking their lives on the job, it's that bad. Don't risk it.

cons:

- Arrogant management: Threatened to fire people when they asked simple questions or wanted to know something more

review_title: Great, easy-going, forward-thinking place to work where you could make a real difference
pros: Desire to improve and become a forward thinking, modern university. Moving to a new campus. The focus on using new digital technologies to enhance learning and teaching as well as professional services.
cons: Structure means the work of each of the schools is fragmented and there is little communication between them below the senior management level (which they're trying to work on). IT have been going through a lot of changes but seem to be settling.

review_title: I would recommend any highly independent person to apply for the job but also with sufficient teaching knowledge.
pros: The best reason to work in the University of Northampton is that it is full of international student, you do not just have the chance to talk to the local student but also people from all around the world.
cons: The facilities might not as good as you think, the campus is having insufficient computer or area for students. BUT the new campus will be available in 2018 with high-tech facilities for education !

pros: There are none unless you enjoy low pay, redundancy and paying to park.
cons:
The University cares little for its employees and frequently restructures/makes its staff redundant with only the bare minimum notice regardless of family commitments. 

It's an expensive place to work when you factor in the extortionat parking and food costs.

They typically pay well below the average salary for a given profession.

The university treats students like cash cows with education as a secondary concern.

review_title: Working as an academic at Northampton
pros: Departmental colleagues are friendly and the students are wonderful.
cons:
I have been there for over nine years but not encouraged to progress my career development and promotion.  It is mainly a teaching university with increasing focus on vocational, employability and money making courses. 

In about three years time the university will be leaving a lovely leafy campus downsizing to move to a much smaller inner city campus.  The reduction in physical space means that academic staff will no longer have private offices and there will be no lecture halls.  There will be limited, if any, facilities for student and staff parking. 

The decision to sell the existing campus and borrow a lot of money to build a new smaller campus was quite sudden and not based on any rationale. No compelling reason for the sale was communicated to staff.  No options were discussed and staff were not consulted in any meaningful or effective way.  It was driven through by the senior management team seemingly on a personal whim.

We are asked to modify our pedagogic practice not in order to enhance the student experience but in order to mitigate the adverse impact of the move to a smaller and limited campus.

The financial consequences of the move have placed a disproportionate and and adverse impact on university finances and resources. This means that experienced staff have been cut and retiring staff not replaced. Budgets for conference and research have been limited, and support for academic events is offered on the basis of the potential earnings the enterprise may bring in.

In order to try to meet the reduction in staff educational and support services have been mechanised  with over reliance on central electronic systems.  the consequence of this is that academic staff are asked to fill in the gaps and do more and more work that previously would have been undertaken by administrative and support staff. The systems appear to be introduced almost on an ad hoc basis without any consultation or reason being given.

The disregard  for academic autonomy and freedom is reflected in the use of metrics and manipulation of staff to promote a corporate plan and marketing image.

pros: The support provided by colleagues and management enhanced the quality of the working experience. They welcomed feedback and suggestions and made changes based on employee recommendations.
cons: The pay wasn't great and I and my colleagues would have preferred a longer contract for job security.
